dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Description
dataObjects.title: Description
dataObjects.rightsHolder: Mark Hyde, Bart Wursten and Petra Ballings
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation:
Hyde, M.A., Wursten, B.T. and Ballings, P. (2002-2014). Azolla pinnata R. Br.
subsp. africana (Desv.) R.M.K. Saunders & K. Fowler Flora of Zimbabwe website. Accessed 28 August 2014 at http://www.zimbabweflora.co.zw/speciesdata/species.php?species_id=102920
dataObjects.description: Small floating ferns, whole plant oblong to deltoid in outline, up to 20 × 15 mm. Rhizome up to 0.2 mm in diameter, horizontal,  branched into 3-5 alternate pinnae. Roots single or in fascicles of 2-3 at the branche nodes, up to 3.5 cm long, hairy, with conspicuous root cap. Leaves minute in 2 rows, dark green, 2-lobed; upper lobe up to 1.1 mm long, ovate to broadly elliptic in outline, apex pointed,  papillate in the centre and with a hyaline border; lower lobe colourless, more or less equal in size. Plant heterosporous, sporocarps on the submerged lower lobes of the leaves.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Miscellaneous Details
dataObjects.description: "There are three subordinate taxa of Azolla pinnata depending on the range of occurence. A. pinnata africana is found Africa, A. pinnata asiatica in Asia and A. pinnata pinnata in Oceania."

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Brief
dataObjects.description: "Red List Category & Criteria: Least Concern ver 3.1 Year Assessed: 2010 Assessor/s: Gupta, A.K. Reviewer/s: Juffe Bignoli, D., Khampheng, H. & Zhuang, X. Justification: This aquatic fern is common in tropical regions of the world where it occurs in stagnant water. It can spread rapidly in and around rivers, ditches, and ponds and even in eutrophic waters. Listed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species and faces no major threats. Conservation Actions: No conservation measures are in place or needed."

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.title: Range Description
dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.rightsHolder: International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Gupta, A.K. 2013. Azolla pinnata. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description: It is fairly common in tropical regions of the world. Its native range includes Africa and Madagascar, India, southeast Asia, China (Anhui, Fujian, Henan, Hubei, Jiangsu, Jiangxi, Sichuan, Zhejiang), Japan, Malaysia and Australia. It has also been recorded in Viet Nam, Lao PDR and Cambodia.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.title: Distribution
dataObjects.description: "Range Description: It is fairly common in tropical regions of the world. Its native range includes Africa and Madagascar, India, southeast Asia, China (Anhui, Fujian, Henan, Hubei, Jiangsu, Jiangxi, Sichuan, Zhejiang), Japan, Malaysia and Australia. It has also been recorded in Viet Nam, Lao PDR and Cambodia. Countries -  Native: Angola; Australia (New South Wales, Northern Territory, Queensland); Bangladesh; Bhutan; Botswana; Burundi; Cambodia; Cape Verde; Central African Republic; China (Anhui, Fujian, Guangdong, Guangxi, Guizhou, Henan, Hubei, Jiangsu, Jiangxi, Yunnan); Congo; Gabon; Guinea; Hong Kong; India; Indonesia; Japan; Kenya; Lao People's Democratic Republic; Liberia; Madagascar; Malaysia; Mozambique; Myanmar; New Zealand; Nigeria; Papua New Guinea; Philippines; Rwanda; Senegal; Sierra Leone; South Africa (KwaZulu-Natal); Sri Lanka; Taiwan, Province of China; Tanzania, United Republic of; Thailand; Uganda; Viet Nam; Zambia"

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObjects.title: General Habitat
dataObjects.description: "Habitat and Ecology: The plant is an aquatic fern of stagnant water. It can spread rapidly, and has the ability to survive on moist soil in and around rivers, ditches, and ponds. In eutrophic waters, it forms dense surface mats, which degrade water quality by reducing oxygen levels. Systems: Freshwater List of Habitats: 5, 5.4, 5.5, 5.7"

Year Assessed
2013

Assessor/s
Gupta, A.K.

Reviewer/s
Juffe Bignoli, D., Khampheng, H. & Zhuang, X.

Contributor/s

Justification

This aquatic fern is common in tropical regions of the world where it occurs in stagnant water. It can spread rapidly in and around rivers, ditches, and ponds and even in eutrophic waters. Listed as Least Concern as it is a widespread species and faces no major threats.
